metadata.title: Highly selective IrMo/TiO<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> catalyst for hydrogenation of nitroarene<ce:bold>s</ce:bold>

Highly selective IrMo/TiO2 catalyst for hydrogenation of nitroarenes Jiarui Zhao a b Lingzhe Fang c Junhong Fu a ⁎ Jian Wang a Qike Jiang a Tao Li c d ⁎ Jiahui Huang a b ⁎ a Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian Liaoning 116023 China aDalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China bUniversity of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China c Chemistry and Biochemistry Department, Northern Illinois University, Illinois, United States of America Chemistry and Biochemistry Department Northern Illinois University Illinois United States of America cChemistry and Biochemistry Department, Northern Illinois University, Illinois, United States of America d Chemistry and Material Science Group, X-ray Science Division, Argonne National Laboratory, United States of America Chemistry and Material Science Group X-ray Science Division Argonne National Laboratory United States of America dChemistry and Material Science Group, X-ray Science Division, Argonne National Laboratory, United States of America ⁎ Corresponding authors. The performance of many supported metal catalysts is markedly enhanced by promoters. Here, we demonstrate the introduction of Mo into TiO2-supported IrMo catalysts greatly boosts the 3-vinylaniline (3-VA) selectivity of the hydrogenation of 3-nitrostyrene (3-NS). With the rise of Mo component in IrMo/TiO2 catalysts, the Ir that activate H2 are surrounded by more Mo species and become more oxidized, which prevents flat adsorption of 3-NS on Ir; meanwhile, Mo(V) species that are favorable for activation of nitro group of 3-NS increase, thus the synergistic effect affords excellent 3-VA selectivity. The optimal catalyst 1Ir9Mo/TiO2 displays 99.8% selectivity of 3-VA at a 100% conversion. It also shows good recyclability and universality in selectively reducing unsaturated nitroarenes to corresponding anillines with exceptional selectivity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Promotional effect Mo5+ species Synergistic catalysis, 3-nitrostyrene 3-vinylaniline Hydrogenation of nitroarenes Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Functionalized anilines, essential intermediates for the production of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, pigments and dyes, have made up a huge part of the organic chemical market [1]. Catalytic hydrogenation of nitroarenes to anilines is a promising industrial process with great advantages in low cost and environmental friendliness [2]. Selective hydrogenation of nitroarenes with molecular hydrogen catalyzed by metals [1,3], especially precious metals like Pt [4–7], Pd [8], Ir [9,10] have attracted great attention due to the their extremely high activities, but these catalysts showed unsatisfactory selectivities for some functionalized anilines, which is primarily caused by the adsorption of nitroaromatics in a flat manner that makes both the nitro group and the functionalized group available for hydrogenation, thus resulting in relatively poor selectivities [6,8,11,12]. Promoter by itself has little or no catalytic activity, but is able to facilitate catalytic performance for many important reactions such as Fischer–Tropsch synthesis [13] and water-gas shift [14]. Elements of Sn [15,16], Mo [17,18], Fe [6,9], Pb [19], Bi [20], Na [21] have displayed promotional effects for enhanced activity or/and selectivities towards the catalytic hydrogenation of nitroarenes. These promoters boosted the adsorption of nitroaromatic molecules via nitro group on the catalyst and by all means mitigated the flat adsorption of nitroaromatic molecules. However, it still remains a grand challenge to obtain high selectivity and high activity simultaneously, even with the use of promoters. In this work, we discover that the introduction of Mo into the Ir/TiO2 catalyst greatly boosts the reaction activity and selectivity towards the hydrogenation of 3-nitrostyrene (3-NS) to 3-vinylaniline (3-VA) in comparison to the Ir/TiO2 catalyst. The optimal catalyst 1Ir9Mo/TiO2 displays 99.8% selectivity of 3-VA at a conversion of 100%, moreover, it shows 99.9% selectivity in the reduction of eight unsaturated nitroarenes. Comprehensive characterizations show that with the increase of Mo in the IrMo/TiO2 catalysts, the Ir species are surrounded by Mo species, and the content of Mo(V) species gradually rise. We propose that the Mo species that encircle the Ir species supresses the flat adsorption of 3-NS on Ir species, making Ir species activating H2, and the Mo(V) species activate 3-NS via nitro group, the synergy of Ir and Mo(V) afford excellent selectivity of 3-VA. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals were used as received without further purification. Iridium trichloride (IrCl3, 98%), (E)−1-nitro-4-(2-phenylethenyl)benzene (98%), 4-nitrobenzyl alcohol (99%), 4-nitroacetophenone (98%), 4-nitrostyrene (98%+), 2-nitrophenol (99%+) and 4-nitrostyrene (98%+) were purchased from Adamas. Ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24▪4H2O, 99.0%) and m-xylene was purchased from Kermel. TiO2 (rutile, 25 nm, 99.8%) and o-chloronitrobenzene (99%) were purchased from Aladdin. 3-nitrostyrene (3-NS, 97%), p-bromonitrobenzene (98%) and p-iodonitrobenzene (98%) were purchased from Acros. 4-nitrobenzonitrile (98%) was purchased from TCI. The aqueous solutions used in this work were all prepared with ultrapure water (Millipore Milli-Q, >18.2 MΩ cm). 2.2 Catalyst preparation All the catalysts were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method. TiO2 (rutile, 1 g) was added to the aqueous solution containing the Ir or/and Mo precursors (IrCl3 and (NH4)6Mo7O24▪4H2O), after being vigorously stirred for 10 h, the mixture was dried at 70 °C for 12 h. The resultant solid was heated under argon at 450 °C for 2 h, affording 1Ir/TiO2, 9Mo/TiO2, and 1IrxMo/TiO2 (x = 2, 5, 7, 9) based on the weight percent of each metallic component on the catalyst. The metal loadings were determined by the inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) analysis (Table S1). The synthesis of 1Pt/TiO2 and 1Pt9Mo/TiO2, 1Pd/TiO2 and 1Pd9Mo/TiO2, were similar to that of 1Ir/TiO2 and 1Ir9Mo/TiO2, only by replacing IrCl3 with H2PtCl6 and (NH4)2PdCl4. 2.3 Characterizations The as-synthesized samples were characterized without pre-treatment. Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) was conducted using PerkinElmer ICP-OES 7300DV. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was recorded on a PANanlytical X'pert-Pro-diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation in the range of 10°−80° using a step size of 0.33°. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were carried out using Micromeritics Autochem II 2920. Each sample (50 mg) was placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor. To remove traces of water in the samples, it was purged with flowing Ar (10 cm3/min) at 120 ℃ for 2 h and then cooled down to room temperature. Then the gas was switched to H2/Ar (10%, flowing rate: 10 cm3/min), it was heated from room temperature to 700 ℃ with a heating rate of 10 ℃/min. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution (HR)-TEM images were taken by JEM-2100 apparatus (JEOL). High-angle annular dark-field (HAADF)−STEM images and element mappings were obtained on a JEOL JEM ARM200F instrument. Particle size distribution of 1Ir9Mo/TiO2 and 1Ir/TiO2 was based on 111 and 96 particles respectively. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted using Thermo Fisher Excalab X+. Binding energy values were calibrated with respect to the C 1 s position (284.6 eV). The resulting spectra were fitted by using a Shirley background and by using a Gaussian−Lorentzian peak shape. The Mo 3d spectra curve fit included both Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 lines, fixing the intensity ratio between Mo 3d5/2 spectra and Mo 3d3/2 spectra to a value of about 1.5 and a binding energy separation of the Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 lines to 3.2 eV. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was carried out on a Bruker A200 spectrometer with a 9.33 GHz X-band. The X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements at the Ir L3-edge were performed on the bending-magnet beamlines 12-BM and 20-BM of the Advanced Photon Source (APS) at the Argonne National Laboratory (ANL). A Ir metal foil was used to calibrate the X-ray beam energy and was simultaneously measured with each sample. XAS spectra were collected in fluorescence and transmission mode. XAS data were processed by Athena software. 2.4 Catalytic measurements Hydrogenation of 3-NS was performed in a stainless-steel autoclave (25 mL) equipped with a pressure gage and magnetic stirrer. A mixture of 3-NS, catalyst and solvent was placed into a quartz vessel, which was then put into the autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and purged with hydrogen at least five times and finally charged with 2 MPa hydrogen. The reaction time commenced after reaching the set temperature. After the reaction ended, it was cooled down to room temperature followed by releasing the remaining hydrogen gas. The stirring speed was 1000 r/min, large enough to eliminate the external diffusion effect. The product was then condensed and analyzed by gas chromatography (7890B)-mass spectrometry (5977A) (GCMS, Agilent) equipped with a capillary HP-5 column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst preparation and catalytic performance The TiO2-supported Ir, Mo, and IrMo samples were prepared by the wetness impregnation method followed with treatment at 450 °C in Ar atmosphere, denoted as 1Ir/TiO2, 9Mo/TiO2, and 1IrxMo/TiO2 (x = 2, 5, 7, 9) based on the weight percent of each metallic component on the catalyst. The metal loadings were determined by the inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) analysis (Table S1). The evaluation of different catalysts towards selective hydrogenation of 3-NS was performed in a batch reactor. The reaction was conducted at 60 °C for 1 hour, and the results are shown in Table 1 . No activity was detected over 9Mo/TiO2, which was as expect. [10] 1Ir/TiO2 displayed 78.9% selectivity of 3-VA at a conversion of 8.1%. After the introduction of Mo, the performances of the IrMo/TiO2 catalysts dramatically enhanced. The reaction activity over 1Ir2Mo/TiO2 increased by 11 times comparing with that of 1Ir/TiO2, and the selectivity of 3-VA rose to 88.5%. The 3-VA selectivity further increased to 95.8% and 99.6% over 1Ir5Mo/TiO2 and 1Ir7Mo/TiO2, respectively. It is noted that 1Ir9Mo/TiO2 showed 99.8% selectivity of 3-VA at a conversion of 39.2%; after the complete conversion of 3-NS, the selectivity of 3-VA still remained 99.8%, which is superior to the vast majority of the reported catalysts. Besides, m-xylene was chosen as the solvent for hydrogenation of 3-NS (Table S2). We also explored TiO2-supported PtMo and PdMo catalysts towards the selective hydrogenation of 3-NS, which showed better selectivity of 3-VA than the corresponding monometallic catalysts (Table S3). These results indicate the promotional effects of Mo. Recyclability investigations on 1Ir9Mo/TiO2 showed the catalyst still maintained 99.8% selectivity after nine cycles (Figure S1), and the activity remained basically constant after the third run. It was then extended to various nitroarenes (eight samples) to evaluate its application potential (Table S4). The selectivities of desired products were > 99.9% for carbonyl, ketone, nitrile, hydroxyl, and halogen-substituted nitroarenes, surpassing the vast majority of the previously reported catalysts. 3.2 Structural characterization of catalysts The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns for these samples are shown in Fig. 1 . Peaks assigning to TiO2 (rutile) phase (JCPDS No. 21–1276) were clearly observed, and the peak intensity showed no marked changes, indicating the well-maintained TiO2 crystallinity. Notably, the characteristic peak at 27.5° (2θ) shifted to a lower degree than the pristine TiO2, implying that Ir or/and Mo are doped into the lattice of TiO2. [22,23] The surface area of the IrMo/TiO2 samples decreased with the rise of Mo content (Table S5), which can be ascribed to the formation of amorphous MoOx on the surface of TiO2 [23]. MoO3 formed as single phase in 9Mo/TiO2 and 1Ir9Mo/TiO2, likely due to the high loadings of Mo on the TiO2 support. Besides, there were no Ir-related phases in the XRD patterns, suggesting the Ir species are highly dispersed or amorphous so that they are not detectable by XRD. Morphological studies were performed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF)-scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM). TEM images of 9Mo/TiO2 are shown in Figure S2, in which no discernible particles of Mo species were observed due to the low Z-contrast between Mo and Ti. HR-TEM images showed a lattice space of 0.33 nm corresponding to the (110) face of rutile (JCPDS No. 76–1940) [24], but longer than that of a typical value (0.32 nm). We infer this is due to Mo being doped into the lattice of rutile. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) further confirmed the presence of Mo in 9Mo/TiO2 (Figure S3). TEM images of 1Ir/TiO2 showed a homogeneous dispersion of Ir particles with a size distribution of 1.5 ± 0.4 nm (Figure S4). The d-space (0.33 nm) of (110) face of rutile was observed in the HRTEM images of 1Ir/TiO2 (Figure S5), similar to that of 9Mo/TiO2; moreover, the lattice space of 0.23 nm corresponding to the (200) face of IrO2 (JCPDS No. 150,870) was observed. Additionally, the existence of Ir element in Ir/TiO2 was further confirmed by EDS (Figure S6). TEM images of 1Ir9Mo/TiO2 displayed the presence of a small number of nanoparticles with a mean size of 2.3 nm (Fig. 2 a). High-resolution TEM images of 1Ir9Mo/TiO2 showed that the nanoparticles are composed of IrO2 with a d-spacing of 0.23 nm corresponding to (200) of IrO2 (Fig. 2b) [25]. Both single atoms and nanoclusters were observed in the HAADF-STEM images (Fig. 2c). Elemental mappings showed atomically dispersed Ir and Mo being the majority species, as well as a small percentage of nanoclusters (Fig. 2d). For those IrO2 nanoclusters, we are uncertain that small amounts of Mo elements are doped into their lattice (Figure S7). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were used to study the oxidation states of Mo. The deconvolved spectra of Mo 3d for the IrMo/TiO2 catalysts showed the presence of Mo5+ and Mo6+ components [23,26] (Fig. 3 a). The Mo5+ percentage showed an increase trending with the rise of the Mo loadings. In particular, the Mo5+ percentage increased from 37% for 1Ir2Mo/TiO2 to 72% for 1Ir9Mo/TiO2, higher than 22% for 9Mo/TiO2. The existence of Mo5+ species was further confirmed by electronic paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurement showing a g value of 1.93 [27,28], and the EPR peak intensity also showed an increasing trend with the rise of the Mo loadings (Fig. 3b), indicative of an increase in the content of Mo5+ species. Due to the overlapped area between Ir 4f spectra and Ti 3s spectra, it is difficult to obtain reasonable results, and the analysis of the Ir 4f spectra was thus skipped. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was performed to investigate the electronic structures and coordination environment of Ir species. The Ir L3-edge XANES spectra of 1Ir/TiO2, 1Ir2Mo/TiO2 and 1Ir9Mo/TiO2 with Ir foil and IrO2 as references are shown in Fig. 4 a. The white line of these samples were similar to that of IrO2, indicative of a similar structure to IrO2. Subtle differences were observed in the white-line intensities, and a further comparison shows the white line intensity increases in the order of 1Ir/TiO2 < 1Ir2Mo/TiO2 < 1Ir9Mo/TiO2, which implies that the oxidation states of Ir increase in the same order. Fourier transforms of the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) of Ir L3-edge for 1Ir/TiO2, 1Ir2Mo/TiO2 and 1Ir9Mo/TiO2 with Ir foil and IrO2 bulk as references are shown in Fig. 4b, from which the local structural environments of the Ir element can be deduced. Two major peaks at about 1.7 Å and 2.7 Å corresponding to Ir-O and Ir-Ir scatterings respectively were observed [29]. The length of Ir-O bond gradually becomes shorter with the increase of Mo component, indicating the Ir-O bonds were modulated by the surrounding Mo species. The Mo K edge XANES spectra of 1Ir2Mo/TiO2 and 1Ir9Mo/TiO2 are shown in Figure S8a. The shape and height of the white line of these samples closely resembled that of MoO3, [30] indicating the highly oxidation state of the Mo species. The position of the white line for 1Ir2Mo/TiO2 is stronger than that for 1Ir9Mo/TiO2, indicative of a higher Mo oxidation state of 1Ir9Mo/TiO2, in agreement with the XPS and EPR results. EXAFS of Mo K edge for 1Ir9Mo/TiO2 showed the existence of Mo-O bond and Mo-Mo bond, while 1Ir2Mo/TiO2 only showed the presence of Mo-O bond (Figure S8b), suggestive of well-dispersed Mo species, agreeing with the XRD patterns. The interaction between Ir and Mo was investigated by hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements (Fig. 5 ). 1Ir/TiO2 displayed a reduction peak from 220 to 270 °C, whereas 9Mo/TiO2 showed a broad peak from 330 to 550 °C. By contrast, the IrMo/TiO2 catalysts showed much lower reduction temperatures in the range of 30–100 °C, which can be assigned to the formation a new interphase between oxidized Ir and Mo species with a much higher oxidation state than 1Ir/TiO2, thus resulting in a significantly lower reduction temperature. In the profiles of the IrMo/TiO2 catalysts, with the increase of Mo content, the first TPR peaks (in the range of 30–100 °C) shifted to higher temperatures, which can be taken as a fingerprint to study the interaction between Ir species and Mo species. As proposed for reducing CoMo and NiMo catalysts, [31,32] with the increasing amount of neighbouring oxidized Mo species with empty d orbitals, Ir-O bonds might be polarized and became more ionic, which means an increase for the Ir oxidation states. Moreover, with the increasing amount of Mo species around of Ir species, the Ir oxides become more highly dispersed, which makes it more difficult to be reduced, thus resulting in an enhanced reduction temperature. As the Ir oxide species become more dispersed with the increasing Mo content, the interphase became more ubiquitous, thus consumed more H2. 3.3 Discussions To clarify the structure-activity relation, the catalytic selectivity was plotted as a function of the molar ratios between the content Mo(V) species and the content of Ir species in each IrMo/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 6 ). The calculations were listed in Table S6. The molar ratios of Mo(V)/Ir of different IrMo/TiO2 catalysts increased with the rise of Mo loadings. The selectivity of 3-VA increased with the rise of this molar ratio, suggesting the content of Mo(V) was critical to the enhanced selectivity. The optimal catalyst 1Ir9Mo/TiO2 showed a molar ratio of 15.97. Besides, the activity gradually decreased with the increase of Mo loadings, which can be attributed to the gradually weakened ability in H2 activation, evidenced by the TPR profiles. We also carried out investigations on the spent catalyst of 1Ir9Mo/TiO2. The ICP results showed decreased loadings of Ir and Mo elements (Table S1), indicative of leaching of the metals during the recycling reactions. The Ir 4f XPS spectra showed no significant shift in binding energy (Figure S9), suggestive of similar Ir oxidation states in the pristine and used catalyst. TEM images of the used catalyst showed relatively reduced amounts of IrO2 clusters, suggesting the IrO2 clusters leached in the reaction (Figure S10). The percentage of Mo(V) species of the used catalyst dropped to 46.0%, as shown in the Mo 3d spectra (Figure S11). It is noteworthy that the Mo(V)/Ir molar ratio for the spent catalyst was 10.39, between that of 1Ir7Mo/TiO2 (9.37) and 1Ir9Mo/TiO2 (15.97) (Table S5), which further indicates the content of Mo(V) species are the key to the selectivity of 3-VA. It was reported that oxophilic metals with low oxidation states like Pb [19], Fe [6] are favourable to the nitro group of 3-NS, allowing us to propose that the Mo(V) species in the IrMo/TiO2 catalysts were the active sites for the adsorption of the nitro group of 3-NS. The above characterizations on IrMo/TiO2 catalysts showed that with the introduction of Mo, Ir become more oxidized and surrounded by Mo species with the formation of a new interphase that consists of weak interactions between Ir and Mo. The presence of sufficient Mo species around Ir species could prohibit the flat adsorption of 3-NS, which makes Ir species activating H2, meanwhile, the neighbouring Mo(V) species favor the preferential adsorption 3-NS via the nitro group, which account for the excellent selectivity of 3-VA over the 1Ir9Mo/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 7 ). In short, the cooperation of Ir species for the activation of H2 and Mo(V) species for the adsorption of 3-NS via nitro group boosted the selective hydrogenation of 3-NS to 3-VA. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have presented that the promotional effects of Mo in IrMo/TiO2 catalysts boost the selectivity of the hydrogenation of 3-NS into 3-VA. The optimal catalyst 1Ir9Mo/TiO2 displays 99.8% selectivity of 3-VA at a 100% conversion, which is superior to the previously reported catalysts. And the catalyst also shows high stability and universality in selectively reducing unsaturated nitroarene to corresponding anilines with excellent selectivites. The introduction of Mo into IrMo/TiO2 makes Ir species surrounded by Mo species, which could suppress the flat adsorption of 3-NS on Ir species, thus enabling the H2 activation on Ir species; and with the rise of Mo content, Mo(V) species that are favorable to the activation of the nitro group of 3-NS increase, the synergistic effect of Ir and Mo(V) thus affords enhanced selectivity. coredata.dc:description: The performance of many supported metal catalysts is markedly enhanced by promoters. Here, we demonstrate the introduction of Mo into TiO2-supported IrMo catalysts greatly boosts the 3-vinylaniline (3-VA) selectivity of the hydrogenation of 3-nitrostyrene (3-NS). With the rise of Mo component in IrMo/TiO2 catalysts, the Ir that activate H2 are surrounded by more Mo species and become more oxidized, which prevents flat adsorption of 3-NS on Ir; meanwhile, Mo(V) species that are favorable for activation of nitro group of 3-NS increase, thus the synergistic effect affords excellent 3-VA selectivity. The optimal catalyst 1Ir9Mo/TiO2 displays 99.8% selectivity of 3-VA at a 100% conversion. It also shows good recyclability and universality in selectively reducing unsaturated nitroarenes to corresponding anillines with exceptional selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Highly selective IrMo/TiO2 catalyst for hydrogenation of nitroarenes
